bestBHT.bht: Prompted by the Spirit, Simeon was led to the temple at the very moment when Jesus was being presented to the Lord. Simeon's steps were guided by the Spirit, as he walked with God in his spiritual condition, recognizing Jesus as the promised Messiah. Through the Spirit's direction, Simeon arrived at the temple to perform the customary rituals according to the law. This divine encounter was orchestrated by the Spirit of God, who knew the exact time for Jesus' arrival.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the temple at the very moment when the Virgin was about to present
Albert Barnes: By the Spirit - By the direction of the Spirit.
Into the temple - Into that part of the temple where the public worship was chiefly performed.
The custom of the law - That is, to make an offering for purification, and to present him to God.
Marvin Vincent: By the Spirit [εν τω πνευματι] . Lit., as Rev., 'in the Spirit :' the Holy Spirit prompting him."
Indicating rather his spiritual condition, as one who walked with God, than a special divine impulse.
After the custom [κατα το ειθισμενον] . Lit., according to that which was wont to be done.
Philip Schaff: His steps were ordered by the Spirit, in the power of which he lived.
The Spirit led him thither to meet this child, whom he was enabled, by the same Spirit, to recognize as the Messiah.
The Spirit led him thither to meet this child, whom he was enabled, by the same Spirit, to recognize as the Messiah.
Archibald T. Robertson: A neat Greek and Hebrew idiom difficult to render into English, very common in the LXX."
The articular infinitive and two accusatives (one the object, the other accusative of general reference).
The perfect passive participle ειθισμενον, neuter singular from εθιζω (common Greek verb, to accustom) is used as a virtual substantive like το εθος in Luke 1:8.
John Gill: The Spirit of God, who knows and searches all things, even the deep things of God, and could testify beforehand the sufferings of Christ, and the glory that should follow, knew the exact time when Jesus would be brought into the temple.
The Persic version spoils the glory of the text, making Simeon's coming into the temple, to be upon a report heard, and not the motion of the Holy Ghost.
To do for him after the custom of the law; as was used to be done in such a case, according to the appointment of the law.
John Wesley: By the Spirit — By a particular revelation or impulse from him.

bhtAttempts.bht: Prompted by the Spirit, Simeon was guided to the temple at the precise moment the Virgin Mary was presenting Jesus to the Lord. Simeon's steps were ordered by the Spirit, as he walked with God in his spiritual condition. The Spirit led him to meet the Messiah and recognize Jesus as the promised Savior. Through the Spirit's guidance, Simeon arrived at the temple to perform the customary rituals according to the law. The Spirit of God, who knows all things, orchestrated this divine encounter in perfect accordance with the appointed time.

Prompted by the Spirit, Simeon was led to the temple at the very moment when Jesus was being presented to the Lord. Simeon's steps were guided by the Spirit, as he walked with God in his spiritual condition, recognizing Jesus as the promised Messiah. Through the Spirit's direction, Simeon arrived at the temple to perform the customary rituals according to the law. This divine encounter was orchestrated by the Spirit of God, who knew the exact time for Jesus' arrival.

Prompted by the Spirit, Simeon arrived at the temple at the same time as the Virgin Mary presented Jesus to the Lord. His steps, guided by the Spirit, reflected his close relationship with God rather than a specific divine impulse. Simeon recognized Jesus as the promised Messiah and the Spirit led him to this destined encounter. The Spirit orchestrated their meeting according to the customs and laws of the time, fulfilling the divine plan set in motion long ago.

Prompted by the Spirit, Simeon arrived at the temple when Jesus was presented to the Lord. His steps were guided by the Spirit, reflecting his close relationship with God. Simeon recognized Jesus as the promised Messiah through the Spirit's leading. This divine encounter was orchestrated according to the customs and laws of the time. The Spirit, who knows all things, planned and arranged the precise timing of this significant event.

By the Spirit, Simeon was guided to the temple at the very moment when the Virgin was about to present Jesus to the Lord. His steps were prompted by the Spirit, reflecting his close relationship with God. Simeon's arrival at the temple, to meet and recognize Jesus as the Messiah, was orchestrated by the same Spirit. The Spirit's leading brought him to the temple to fulfill the customary rituals in accordance with the law. This divine encounter, foreknown by the Spirit, happened precisely as planned.
